comments:
This class teaches the fundamentals of biological chemistry, including the
structure of biological macromolecules and their mechanism of action, intermediary
metabolism, and the chemical basis of information transfer.
Students found that this class covered a lot of material and involved a lot of
memorization. Some complained that the tests focus on “minutiae that are barely
addressed in lectures.” Some felt that they tested your ability to “cram and copy form a
cheat sheet” rather than testing students’ understanding of concepts.
Students generally found Professor Cooperman accessible. Students liked that he
presented his lectures slowly, as there was a lot material to absorb.
Students found the course very difficult, but “manageable if you have time.”
Some noted that having some background in organic chemistry would be very helpful.

This course covers the fundamentals of biological chemistry, including the
structure of biological macromolecules and their mechanism of action, intermediary
metabolism, and the chemical basis of information transfer.
Most of the material was well-received, though some students wished the focus
had been better delegated to important topics rather than ones that did not appear heavily
on exams. For instance, one student noted that there was too much time spent on the
“specifics of proteins,” which did not help in conceptual and theoretical understanding of
the material.
Students complained that because of his accent and his tendency to be “softspoken,”
Professor Baumgart was sometimes difficult to understand, which made
learning new key words and concepts difficult. One student wished that Professor
Baumgart showed a little more “enthusiasm” for the material, while others found him
interesting and willing to answer all questions.
The prerequisite for this course is CHEM 102 while the co-requisite is CHEM
241. Some students felt that this course covered “a ridiculous amount of material.”
Students recommend a background in organic chemistry as this course is “mechanismbased.”
The exams were also considered difficult and some students complained that they
focused too much on minute details in the face of the vast quantity of material that was
covered in class.
